title: 115_s2450
content: The Act titled "Poverty Measurement Improvement Act" aims to enhance the measurement of poverty in the United States. The Act "Poverty Measurement Improvement Act" defines "Federal means-tested benefit" as assistance provided under various programs including Supplemental Security Income, Earned Income Tax Credit, Additional Child Tax Credit, Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, and Medicaid. The Act "Poverty Measurement Improvement Act" defines "Federal means-tested benefit" as assistance provided under various programs including State Children's Health Insurance Program, Refundable Premiums and Out of Pocket Subsidies under the Patient Protection and Affordable Health Care Act, Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Food Program, Women, Infant and Children Food Program, School Breakfast, Section 8 Housing, Public Housing, Home Investment Partnership Program, and Rural Housing Insurance Fund. The term "total family income" in the context of rural housing services under Agriculture refers to the sum of money income earned by household members and Federal means-tested benefits received, minus State and Federal taxes. The term "income tax data" refers to return information disclosed to the Census Bureau under the Internal Revenue Code. The term "administering agency" includes various State and Federal agencies responsible for administering Federal means-tested benefits. During fiscal years 2019 to 2028, a new poverty measurement survey will combine survey, administrative, and income data to accurately determine poverty levels. Personally identifiable information includes data collected by the Census Bureau or disclosed to them by administering agencies. The Director refers to the head of the Census Bureau. The Director will conduct a new survey to determine poverty levels in the United States, using data from the Current Population Survey, administering agencies, and income tax data. The survey will also include questions about incarceration history. The Director will collect data on income and means-tested benefits from individuals who have been incarcerated or are on probation. Administering agencies will provide necessary data, including income tax information, for this purpose. The Director will cover expenses for obtaining the required data. The Director of the Bureau of the Census will publish survey methods, household numbers, response rates, and completion extent. Tables and graphs will display poverty rates and related data calculated from survey responses and other collected data. The Director of the Bureau of the Census will publish survey methods, household numbers, response rates, and completion extent. Tables and graphs will display poverty rates and related data calculated from survey responses and other collected data, including total family income, breakdown of income taxes and payroll taxes paid, and updated poverty thresholds for 2018 and subsequent years. The poverty thresholds will be adjusted using the personal consumer expenditure price index for 2019 and beyond. The Director will create a public database containing data from a survey and other specified information. Personally identifiable information will not be published in any survey information or database. The Bureau of the Census will protect personally identifiable information collected under this Act by removing it from individual records and assigning record identification keys for identification purposes. Security, disclosure, and confidentiality provisions will apply to this information, and only authorized personnel can access it. The Bureau of the Census protects personally identifiable information by assigning record identification keys. Authorized personnel with special sworn status can access this information. Violators face felony charges and fines up to $300,000. Beginning with the first full calendar year after the enactment of this Act, State administering agencies must report annually to the Federal administering agency on households receiving Federal means-tested benefits, identifying them by Social Security number. Data from surveys conducted under subsection (b)(1) is not admissible in any legal proceedings. Violators may face fines up to $300,000 or imprisonment for up to five years under title 18, United States Code. The Bureau of the Census, in coordination with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, will provide summary statistics comparing income levels of respondents to the Consumer Expenditure Survey. Congress believes no additional funds should be allocated for this purpose.
